item.content:encoded:
The Tap Tables

Artist-in-Residency at Autodesk
2015

These investigations focus on how 3D-printed joints can replace wood joinery in furniture assembly. The 3D prints explore formal means of expression unique to the properties of the material, rather than attempting to mimic traditional wooden joints.

The table was first made using an Objet 3D printer, and then – to create a more accessible design – adapted to be printed on a Dremel Ideabuilder, without the need for any support material.

To make your own, go here: http://www.instructables.com/id/Table-with-3D-Printed-Joints/

item.content:encoded:
Incubator Space

VITAL environments, Inc.
Role: Lead Designer & Project Manager
2014

How can you make a space that fosters an innovation community?

Located in downtown Honolulu, this co-working space for a clean energy accelerator and its portfolio companies seeks to provide a flexible work environment and showcase the breadth and reach of its community. Through deep engagement with the client and stakeholders, we crafted a space that reflected the organization’s mission and values, and made a home for its team.

As project lead, responsibilities included the design of the space and custom furniture elements, choosing furnishings and finishes, UX design, documentation, working closely with the client and contractors, and construction administration.

Images and video courtesy of VITAL environments, Inc.

item.content:encoded:
Outdoor Amphitheater

Mark Cavagnero Associates Architects
Role: Project Architect
2012-ongoing

How can an outdoor amphitheater complement its natural setting and create an encompassing environment for its patrons?

The pavilion’s heavy concrete walls contrast with the lightness of the canopy and ground the pavilion in the landscape, while also providing a noise buffer from the surrounding roads. The venue’s flexible design makes it suitable for a variety of performances. The intimacy of the table seating at the terraces is designed to suit orchestra and dance, while the expansive, gently-sloping lawn allows for increased capacity for rock concerts. To stay within a tight budget, all architectural elements also serve structural and acoustical functions.

As project architect, responsibilities include production of all drawings, renderings and 3d models, and coordination with acoustical, theatrical, structural, landscape, MEP, and civil consultants.

Renderings courtesy of Mark Cavagnero Associates Architects.
Site plan courtesy of SWA Group.

Crissy Field Commissary

Mark Cavagnero Associates Architects
Role: Designer
2012

What are the walls of an outdoor room?
How can a building function on the scale of the street and on the scale of the city?

This proposal for the renovation of the existing commissary seeks to fill a gap in the rhythm along Mason Street, which is otherwise composed of long, white buildings with gabled roofs. The design integrates this simple form into a new addition fronting the street, while maintaining the existing column-and-frame structure in the renovated portion of the building.

As the designer for this proposal, responsibilities included production of all images. Blocks of color and sans-serif text were used to evoke the simple forms of the existing buildings on the site and its expansive natural setting.

item.title: Monumental Lightness
item.dc:creator: veraseatonshur
item.description: Monumental Lightness Harvard Graduate School of Design Master of Architecture Thesis Advisor: John Hong 2011 How can a monument to the past remain relevant in the present? The emergence of the digital archive has engendered a mania to gather, catalogue, and store everything without regard for its relative value and place within history. Though archiving […]
item.content:encoded:
Monumental Lightness

Harvard Graduate School of Design
Master of Architecture Thesis
Advisor: John Hong
2011

How can a monument to the past remain relevant in the present?

The emergence of the digital archive has engendered a mania to gather, catalogue, and store everything without regard for its relative value and place within history. Though archiving can be seen as an act of preservation, it is also an act of destruction. Entombing information offers a means of destroying it to liberate the future from the past. Thus, forgetting is the companion of archiving. Andreas Huyssen writes of a “major and puzzling contradiction in our culture. The undisputed waning of history and historical consciousness, the lament about political, social and cultural amnesia…have been accompanied in the past decade and a half by a memory boom of unprecedented proportions.” What is missing from this odd partnership of the past and the future is any sense of the present, of the processes of change, of the awareness of existing in a particular cultural moment.

In this proposal for a language archive, the structure of the building acts as a metaphor for the content it contains. The tensile pods holding each language library are aurally and structurally interlinked, creating reverberations throughout the archive that demonstrate the languages’ connectivity to one another and their continual evolution.

A traditional archive mediates content through a curator. The digital archive, a recent typology, contains no hierarchy. This building defines an alternate relationship between archivist, content, and audience. Within it, architecture acts as the curator between the digital archive and the public.

A deployable market composed of re-configurable canopies charts a series of paths through the old city of L’Aquila, Italy, […]
item.content:encoded:
Mobile Market

Harvard Graduate School of Design
Studio: Post-disaster Architecure
Critics: Shigeru Ban and Danielle Etzler
In collaboration with Christina Cho
2010

How can a simple object spur a region’s recovery effort after a natural disaster?

A deployable market composed of re-configurable canopies charts a series of paths through the old city of L’Aquila, Italy, which was recently devastated by an earthquake. The market brings in much needed commerce and encourages residents to return to the city center.

The individual umbrellas can be fully opened and placed in the piazzas to form a field of arches that house a market. In their closed positions, the umbrellas can be placed along streets to chart the course of the rebuilding effort. The umbrellas are primary constructed of cheap, easily obtainable materials: pvc piping, plywood, and kite parts. Components that require specialized materials and machinery, such as the stainless steel joints, are designed to be small and packed flat to ship.

item.content:encoded:
Refabricating Fisac

Harvard Graduate School of Design
Refabricating Tectonic Prototypes
Critic: Leire Asensio Villoria
In collaboration with Sean Corriel, Andrew Domnitz
2010

When can a beam be more than structural?

Drawing inspiration from the Catalan architect Miguel Fisac’s light diffusing beam sections, this project seeks to invent a parametrically adaptable beam profile that can be shaped to optimize various structural and lighting needs. Whereas Fisac’s beams are uni-directional, the proposed system functions multi-dimensionally. It is structurally adaptive to resist moment and torque brought about by curved conditions. The system is further optimized for natural light levels and solar orientation.

item.title: PlaySound PlayGround
item.dc:creator: veraseatonshur
item.description: PlaySound Playground Harvard Graduate School of Design Moment of the Monument Professor: Jeffrey Schnapp In collaboration with Julian Wu 2010 How can a monument communicate with children through play? According to the writer Robert Musil, the fate of monuments is to be “conspicuously inconspicuous.” The PlaySound PlayGround, a monument to the endangered languages of the […]
item.content:encoded:
PlaySound Playground

Harvard Graduate School of Design
Moment of the Monument
Professor: Jeffrey Schnapp
In collaboration with Julian Wu
2010

How can a monument communicate with children through play?

According to the writer Robert Musil, the fate of monuments is to be “conspicuously inconspicuous.” The PlaySound PlayGround, a monument to the endangered languages of the Caucasus, remains meaningful by being “inconspicuously conspicuous.” The PlaySound encourages active participation and engagement with its subject matter by integrating itself into the daily life of children. Its dual functionality as a monument and a playground creates an ambient learning experience without calling attention to itself. It does not rely on written plagues or static symbols to impart meaning. Rather, it creates a dynamic, interactive atmosphere that orchestrates and accommodates the way that children play.

Children’s stories are often the most effective vehicles for passing on cultural traditions and maintaining an active language. The PlaySound consists of a series of thirty-four grassy hills, alluding to the topographical variety of the region, each referencing an active North Caucasian language and the recently extinct language of Ubykh. Sensors built into each hill detect weight and movement on the playground equipment and activate a sound-scape of the hill’s particular language in ways specific to its degree of endangerment. Voices reciting fables and stories from each language are projected from hidden speakers in the ground. Because the sensors are sensitive to the number of people on the PlaySound at any given time, as well as their relatives positions, the experience of the monument is always different, and every journey taken through it encounters a unique exposure to sound.

The layout of the hills clusters the three language groups together so that children can register their similarities even if they may not understand the languages themselves. The relative height and isolation of each hill correlates to the number of people left who speak each language as their mother tongue. The tallest, steepest hill, located in the center of the playground, represents Ubykh. By delicately privileging the endangered languages by assigning them to higher hills with greater views, the PlaySound hopes to spark curiosity and elevate the status of these languages in the minds of the children. Ultimately, the monument hopes to curtail, and even reverse, the process of language extinction.

item.title: Lemons of the Sorrentine Peninsula
item.dc:creator: veraseatonshur
item.description: Lemons of the Sorrentine Peninsula: An Integrated Cultural Landscape Harvard Graduate School of Design Penny White Travel and Research Grant In collaboration with Julian Wu 2010 How does agriculture influence culture? How has lemon farming along the Sorrentine Peninsula symbiotically evolved alongside the region’s urban development? The lemon gardens of the Sorrentino-Amalfitana Peninsula represent a […]
item.content:encoded:
Lemons of the Sorrentine Peninsula: An Integrated Cultural Landscape

Harvard Graduate School of Design
Penny White Travel and Research Grant
In collaboration with Julian Wu
2010

How does agriculture influence culture?
How has lemon farming along the Sorrentine Peninsula symbiotically evolved alongside the region’s urban development?

The lemon gardens of the Sorrentino-Amalfitana Peninsula represent a complete integration and co-evolution of an agricultural product with its physical and cultural environment. Over the last 300 years, the demands of lemon tree cultivation have morphed the landscape of the peninsula and influenced patterns of settlement in the area. Lemon tree farming has impacted the physical development of the towns along the coastline, from the density of the population to the shapes of the individual dwellings, through its proliferation and dependency on terraced ground. Though lemon farming in the region is difficult and labor-intensive on account of its severe topography and occasionally adverse weather conditions, the lemon trees play a crucial role in their physical environment by counteracting hydrological instability and erosion of the soil, a phenomenon common in similar areas of Italy.

Biological, social, economic, and institutional factors were evaluated in order to identify sustainable methods of preservation and possible future adaptation. Connections between lemon farming, landscape, and architectural expression were studied to determine the relationships among these elements that make the area an ecologically and culturally successful example of agricultural semi-urbanization.

item.dc:creator: veraseatonshur
item.description: The New Gate: A Train Station for Istanbul Harvard Graduate School of Design Options Studio Critic: Hashim Sarkis 2009 How can a new train station connecting the two halves of Istanbul reorganize and reorient the city? The design for this train station functions as an intermodel urban connector, nested within the surrounding neighborhoods and imposing […]
item.content:encoded:
The New Gate: A Train Station for Istanbul

Harvard Graduate School of Design

Options Studio
Critic: Hashim Sarkis
2009

How can a new train station connecting the two halves of Istanbul reorganize and reorient the city?

The design for this train station functions as an intermodel urban connector, nested within the surrounding neighborhoods and imposing its own order back onto the city. Like the Grand Bazaar, the station is both a continuation of Istanbul’s streets and an autonomous object within the urban fabric. it is able to project its own identity into the city while remaining embedded within the local scale.

The station makes legible the passenger flows that are collected, reorganized, and diverted to their desired modes of transit. The building acts as an aggregation of filaments that bundle or unravel, based on the meeting or diverging of major passenger corridors. To ensure efficiency and clarity, movement of people is highly controlled up until the moment they are released to the train platforms, at which point the regulated environment gives way to an open space of freedom and informality.

item.content:encoded:
Institute for Interfaces in Science and Design

Harvard Graduate School of Design
Studio II
Critic: Mariana Ibanez
2008

What happens when science interfaces with design?

This project explores the intersection of typically isolated programs and the resulting interaction between visitors and research fellows, exhibitions and lab spaces. New volumetric configurations and programmatic opportunities are created when the boundaries of spaces holding discrete functions overlap. Circulation exists in excess to provide choice to visitors, but ultimately the building controls the inhabitant, drawing him back toward the focal areas of activity. The flow through the building can be likened to the pendulum of a clock, constantly oscillating from side to side but always coming to rest in the center.

This dorm integrates public and private programs through section. Large common programs are slotted into either end of the building. Residences located nearest to these public programs are […]
item.content:encoded:
Harvard Undergraduate Housing

Harvard Graduate School of Design
Studio III
Critic: John Hong
2008

How can a student dorm encourage greater awareness and interaction among its residents?

This dorm integrates public and private programs through section. Large common programs are slotted into either end of the building. Residences located nearest to these public programs are deformed sectionally and thus share multiple interfacial surfaces. Residential suites interact with circulation by means of common spaces located on bridges spanning the primary circulation of the building. An ambient awareness develops between inhabitants, day students, and the public through sectional manipulation and an abundance of circulation.

item.description: Double Doors Harvard University Graduate School of Design Critic: Thomas Schroepfer 2007 How can a gate to an alleyway become a catalyst for activity? How can a wall become an inhabited space? Space in an alley between two gallery buildings is reconfigured dynamically by a grid of hollow columns hung on a moving track and […]
item.content:encoded:
Double Doors

Harvard University Graduate School of Design
Critic: Thomas Schroepfer
2007

How can a gate to an alleyway become a catalyst for activity?
How can a wall become an inhabited space?

Space in an alley between two gallery buildings is reconfigured dynamically by a grid of hollow columns hung on a moving track and connected linearly in a tensegrity-like manner. The columns can be moved back and forth on the track to create a tight blockade against both pedestrians and traffic or to be distributed far apart to provide structure for installations. The columns can also be rotated 90 degrees along the track, from a vertical to a horizontal position. Moving one columns affects those attached to it along a line, and the pulley system allows a single person to move an entire row. The street is open to both pedestrians and traffic when all columns are in horizontal position.

item.title: Morgan Library Exhibition
item.dc:creator: veraseatonshur
item.description: Morgan Library Exhibition and Book Mount Imrey Culbert Atelier In collaboration with Craig Intinarelli Role: Project Designer 2005-2006 How can a mass-produced book mount be designed to fit the profile of a specific book? How can exhibition design re-imagine the relationship between viewer and artwork? For its grand re-opening exhibition after a large renovation and […]
item.content:encoded:
Morgan Library Exhibition and Book Mount

Imrey Culbert Atelier
In collaboration with Craig Intinarelli
Role: Project Designer
2005-2006

How can a mass-produced book mount be designed to fit the profile of a specific book?
How can exhibition design re-imagine the relationship between viewer and artwork?

For its grand re-opening exhibition after a large renovation and addition by Renzo Piano, the Morgan Library wanted a book mount that would be representative of the institution. Book mounts are fabricated to fit the profile of a particular book held open to a specific page, and are generally made from extruded or heat-bent plexiglass or foam. They cannot be adapted to hold other books or even other pages within the same book.

Working closely with curators, conservators, and fabricators, we designed a book mount that was sturdy, modular and reusable. The design is composed of a kit of standardized parts that can be assembled to form a customized mount for each book. The bases and angles are created in a pre-set array of sizes to allow for as many types of books and positions as possible.

The Morgan Library’s collection of first edition manuscripts, original sheet music and artists’ sketches composed the bulk of its opening exhibition. The rarity and fragility of such artwork generally discourages visitors from coming too close and looking too deeply. The design of the tilted easel encouraged people to imagine themselves as the artist, to lean in and become more aware of the subtleties and textures of the art.

In addition to the design of the book mount, responsibilities included contributing to the design of the casework and working with curators to create the layout of the exhibition spaces.

item.content:encoded:
Screen/Shelf

Independent Project
2005

How does a screen double as a storage unit?

A screen doubles as a mutable, porous bookshelf that creates varied levels of privacy that change depending on its configuration. Two boards of 3/4” plywood are used to create the six sections of the screen and four shelves that sit within the slots. The slots can also remain open for a greater degree of permeability. The unit can be laid flat or folded and stored when not in use.
